Award.AwardTitle: Support for CPS Week 2016 Student Participation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposal is to enable students from educational institutions in the United States to attend the CPSWeek 2016 collection of conferences, which are to be held April 11-14, 2016, in Vienna, Austria. CPSWeek is an annual international multi-conference for Cyber-Physical Systems, comprising five major multi-day conferences, five one-day workshops, and four one-day tutorials. It moves from country to country each year. Attending the conference will provide students with a unique opportunity to listen and learn from the keynote speeches, presentations, posters and demos on cutting edge topics on cyber-physical systems, and to network with both leaders and other young researchers in this area.

CPS research is expected to have positive societal impacts in many areas, including transportation, energy, agriculture, water/sewage treatment, environmental management and manufacturing systems. These systems must operate safely, dependably, securely, efficiently and respond to events in real time. A key feature of CPS research is the requirement to cooperate across disciplines such as computer science, computer architecture and hardware, material science and sensor design, software engineering, networking, and control engineering. In this inherently interdisciplinary field, where collaborations are essential, meeting other researchers is especially important. This event is especially valuable in this regard, because of the international exposure. There is a very high level of activity and investment in CPS research outside the US including Europe and Asia. For these reasons, strong participation in this event, especially among students (our next generation of researchers) is important to maintaining and advancing CPS research in the US.

Institution.Name: SUNY at Stony Brook
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Outcomes Report

Project title: CPS-Week 2016

With the NSF travel grant award #1620195, the goal of enabling as many students as possible from universities in the United States to attend CPS-Week 2016 in Vienna, Austria was fully accomplished. CPS-Week, and its four constituent conferences, HSCC, ICCPS, ISPN, and RTAS, is a leading international conference which exposes researchers to cutting-edge topics in cyber-physical systems. Through this unique opportunity to attend CPS-Week 2016, students had the chance to further develop their knowledge and experience, network with leaders, and in turn, strengthen America’s competitiveness in the field of cyber-physical systems.

Specifically, this NSF grant enabled 32 students from 20 different educational institutions across the United States to attend CPS-Week’s collection of conferences, keynote speeches, poster sessions, and technical sessions during the week of April 14-17, 2016 in Vienna, Austria. An eighth of the attendees were women and half of them were authors of presented papers which were part of the peer reviewed conference proceedings. The four conferences that comprised CPS Week 2016 https://cpsweek2017.ece.cmu.edu/past/2016/ included 21 workshops, six tutorials, one competition, and three research summits.

Recognized as the Most Successful CPS Week team for attracting the most participants ever (more than US, Europe, Asia), the students positively impacted through this award were from the following institutions:

  • Stony Brook University
  • City University of New York
  • University of Pennsylvania
  • University of Kansas
  • Massachusetts Institute of Technology
  • University of Michigan
  • Illinois Institute of Technology
  • University of Cincinnati
  • University of California – Davis
  • Washington University in St Louis
  • Rutgers University
  • Arizona State University
  • University of Maryland-Baltimore
  • University of North Carolina
  • Vanderbilt University
  • University of California-Berkeley
  • University of Washington
  • University of Houston
  • University of California – Irvine
  • Cornell University

NSF funding offset travel, registration, and hotel accommodations which resulted in each student receiving 90% of their claimed expenses, a total of no more than $1,645. Requests for funding were sent to a committee chaired by the Principal Investigator and selection allowed for attendance by students who could not otherwise have attended, e.g., their research was not funded by any other grant.

In addition to having the opportunity to listen and learn from presentations and demonstrations, the intellectual merit of the conference included students who participated in networking activities fostered by a special “Birds-of-a-Feather” session. During this special sessions students formed relationships with global educators and researchers, as well as sponsors, e.g., Siemens, Microsoft, Mathworks, Google, TATA Consultancy, and Leica Geosystems.

Intellectual merit of the funding was demonstrated by the unique research exposure received by a wide-array of students from across the United States. Broader impact of the funding was highlighted by the number of institutions involved and participants who returned to their universities to further disseminate the conference mission. 

 


Last Modified: 03/13/2018
Modified by: Radu Grosu
